transcript:
Therapist: You've made some excellent points about the importance of self-care and having a plan in place for maintaining your progress, Mei. I'm impressed by your insight and dedication to your mental health. As we wrap up our work together, I want to emphasize that the skills and strategies you've learned in therapy are tools you can continue to use and build upon throughout your life. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there may be times when you face challenges or setbacks. During these moments, it's essential to be kind and compassionate with yourself and to reach out for support when needed.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I feel more prepared to handle challenges now that I have these tools and a better understanding of my thoughts and behaviors. It's been a difficult journey, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the skills I've learned in therapy.

Therapist: You've done an incredible job, Mei, and I'm so proud of the progress you've made. Remember, you have the strength and resilience to continue moving forward, even when things get tough. As we end our session today, I'd like to assign some homework to help you continue practicing your skills. First, keep using thought records to challenge negative thoughts related to self-care, work, and your relationships. Second, review your coping cards and wellness action plan regularly to reinforce the strategies you've learned. Finally, share your relapse prevention plan with Lian and discuss how you can support each other in maintaining your mental health.

Patient: That sounds good, Nova. I'll definitely keep practicing the thought records and reviewing my coping resources. Sharing my relapse prevention plan with Lian is a great idea, too. It will be helpful to have her support and understanding as I continue working on my mental health.

Therapist: Absolutely, Mei. Sharing your plan with Lian can help strengthen your support system and provide a sense of accountability as you continue your journey. Before we end our session, I'd like to do a quick check-in. How are you feeling right now, and do you have any final thoughts you'd like to share?

Patient: I'm feeling a mix of emotions right now. I'm proud of the progress I've made, but I'm also a bit nervous about not having our regular sessions anymore. At the same time, I feel more equipped to handle challenges on my own, knowing that I have these tools and strategies to rely on. I'm grateful for your guidance and support throughout this process, Nova.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel a mix of emotions as we end our therapy sessions, Mei. It's a significant milestone, and it's natural to feel both pride in your progress and some apprehension about the future. Remember, you've developed a strong foundation of skills and insights that you can continue to build upon. And if you ever find yourself in need of additional support, don't hesitate to reach out. I'm always here for you.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. That means a lot to me. I feel more confident knowing that I can always come back if I need help in the future.

Therapist: You're welcome, Mei. It's been an honor to work with you and witness your growth throughout our sessions. I have complete faith in your ability to continue making progress and maintaining your mental health. Remember, you have the strength, resilience, and tools to face any challenges that come your way.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewing progress made in therapy and reinforcing learning
  - Discussing strategies for maintaining progress after therapy ends, including relapse prevention planning
  - Addressing lingering feelings of guilt and worthlessness related to work and self-care
  - Celebrating Mei's achievements and acknowledging ongoing areas for growth

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records to challenge negative thoughts related to self-care and work
  - Review of coping cards and wellness action plan
  - Development of a relapse prevention plan, including identifying early warning signs and strategies for coping
  - Encouragement of sharing progress and relapse prevention plan with partner for additional support
  - Positive Data Log to collect evidence supporting more adaptive beliefs about self (from previous sessions)
  - "I" statements, boundary-setting, and active listening for improving communication with partner (from previous sessions)
  - Downward arrow technique to uncover core beliefs (from previous sessions)
  - Assertiveness training and boundary-setting strategies for work situations (from previous sessions)
  - 5-5-5 mindfulness technique for managing mood fluctuations (from previous sessions)
  - Progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing for relaxation and stress reduction (from previous sessions)
  - Wind-down alarm and consistent sleep schedule for improving sleep hygiene (from previous sessions)

- Homework assigned:
  1. Continue practicing thought records, focusing on catching and challenging negative thoughts related to self-care, work, and relationships
  2. Review coping cards and wellness action plan regularly to reinforce skills and strategies learned in therapy
  3. Share relapse prevention plan with Lian and discuss ways to support each other in maintaining mental health

- Patient's progress, challenges, and important details:
  - Mei has made significant progress in recognizing and challenging negative thoughts, prioritizing self-care, and improving communication with her partner
  - Mei feels more confident in her ability to maintain progress after therapy ends but acknowledges ongoing challenges and the need for continued practice
  - Depression symptoms have improved, but Mei still experiences occasional feelings of guilt and worthlessness related to work and self-care
  - Mei is excited to continue applying skills and strategies independently and feels grateful for the progress she has made in therapy

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I'm only valuable if I'm constantly working hard and putting others' needs before my own"
  - Intermediate belief: "Taking breaks or engaging in self-care means I'm not working hard enough"

- Plan for the future:
  - Mei will continue to apply skills and strategies learned in therapy independently
  - Mei is encouraged to reach out if she needs additional support in the future
  - Therapist reinforces Mei's progress and resilience, emphasizing that the end of therapy is the beginning of a new phase of growth and application of skills
